p: To understand the protective potential of high‐avidity H3‐HA and H3‐stem IgG by eIIV in older adults, especially A‐eIIV, we evaluated the same vaccines in mice (Figure 1e). Mice were vaccinated twice, and post‐vaccination immune responses were assessed at days 7 and 21. The A‐eIIV group had significantly increased day 7 and 21 post‐vaccination magnitude of HA IgG responses to vaccine strains, H1N1‐2009 and H3N2‐2013 HA (Figure 1f), whilst other eIIVs were equivalent to S‐IIV for these HA IgG responses. In addition, the H1N1‐2009 NA IgG response was elevated for A‐eIIV at days 7 and 21 post‐vaccination, whilst H‐eIIV was delayed to until day 21 post‐vaccination compared with S‐IIV (Figure 1f). As R‐eIIV also does not contain NA, no substantial NA‐specific IgG responses were detected. Furthermore, virus neutralisation antibodies (VNAs) at day 7 post‐vaccination (Figure 1g) were significantly increased for A‐eIIV against H1N1‐2009 virus (907 ± 174 versus 293 ± 27 S‐IIV) and H‐eIIV and A‐eIIV against H3N2‐2013 virus compared with S‐IIV.
